@LoganJastremski @pseudotheos With data availability sampling and erasure coding, each node only needs to process a small fraction of the data, which is an incredible advantage.

The processed data then only needs to live on HDDs, not SSDs, making it incredibly cheap to store.

@GuthL @BtcStratum @das_grasshopper @EW___98 @ercwl @epolynya @antiprosynth Which is a legitimate issue, caused by Bitcoin's lack of expressivity

@MacTar8822 The call data in a Validium can't be used by individuals to restore the state of the rollup, which is one of the core properties of on-chain call data rollups. It's the reason why rollups are so secure.

In a validium, the state of the rollup can be frozen.
RT @threepwave: Reminder! @lordOfAFew and I are going live in less than an hour! Weâ€™ll be fielding questions from @LootRealms and @cryptsncâ€¦
@MacTar8822 Yes.

Bitcoin needs a native DA layer, optimally data availability sampling, for this to be viable. If the data availability is not secured by Bitcoin, it more or less defeats the purpose of a zk rollup on top of Bitcoin.

Off-chain DA ofc would still make sense, but way less secure. https://t.co/rayFWJA6Y5
